;中国希望与美国建立健康稳定的关系，但关系已受到损害” 1979年，“中美建交”。

;

;根据国防部官方社交媒体上发布的新闻稿，李将局势恶化归咎于“美方一些人没有与我们同向”

;

;基辛格作为理查德·尼克松的国家安全顾问和国务卿，在 20 世纪 70 年代关系正常化中发挥了关键作用。

;

;“两国之间相互依存的事实是中方敦促美方采取“实际行动”，阻止中美关系进一步下滑。 ;

;“中国正在走和平发展道路，这对世界是福不是祸，美国应该做出正确的战略判断。”

;

;李克强拒绝正式发表声明上个月在新加坡举行的防务峰会上与美国外长劳埃德·奥斯汀会面。一名中国高级将领以美国对李克强实施的制裁为理由——据称他在为中国人民解放军获取俄罗斯武器方面发挥了作用——作为拒绝会面的理由。

;

;北京方面也一直在抵制要求美国军方出动的呼吁。去年 8 月，前众议院议长南希·佩洛西 (Nancy Pelosi) 访问台湾，北京认为这是对其主权的严重侵犯。建设稳定、可预期、建设性的中美关系。”李说。

;

;在谈到去年习近平和拜登的会晤时，他补充道：“我们希望美方与我们共同努力落实两国元首共识，共同推动两国两军关系健康稳定发展。”

;

;基辛格表示，他是“作为两国的朋友”来访的。中方声明称，两国应“消除误解，和平共处，避免对抗”，

;

;“历史和实践不断证明，美国和中国都承受不起今年早些时候已过百岁生日的基辛格说：“两国之间的战争不会给两国人民带来任何有意义的结果。” >;

;他建议解放军和美军加强沟通，“尽最大努力为两国关系发展、维护世界和平稳定创造积极成果”。

;中国领导人习近平和罗德里戈·杜特尔特周一的意外会面是为了争取支持分析人士称，随着马尼拉向华盛顿靠拢，习近平在菲律宾寻求更加友好的对华政策。

;

;周一在北京会谈时，习近平敦促菲律宾前总统杜特尔特“在友好合作中发挥重要作用”习近平表示，以亲华政策闻名的杜特尔特在担任领导人期间做出了改善与北京关系的“战略选择”，这有助于使两国关系“走向正确方向”据国家通讯社新华社报道。

;

;“中方一贯重视中菲关系，愿与菲方共同努力，推动中菲关系行稳致远” ”，习近平说。

;

;近几个月来，由于中国船只侵入南海领土，菲律宾与中国的关系一直紧张。北京声称对南海几乎全部海域拥有主权。

;

;新加坡尤索夫伊萨东南亚研究所客座研究员马波表示，这次会议可以被视为北京“国家元首外交”的延伸，并指出杜特尔特“几乎单枪匹马地改变了”马尼拉的对华政策

;

;“与杜特尔特的接触表明中国 — — 特别是习主席 — — 致力于向那些为加强与中国的双边关系做出贡献的领导人表示敬意，”马云说。南京大学国际关系学院副教授。

;

;“中国显然希望杜特尔特倡导与中国友好关系，但他们也希望他和他的政治联盟批评美菲关系在南中国海以及可能在台湾海峡对中国进行“魅力攻势”。”

;

;在去年上任的小费迪南德·马科斯总统的领导下，这个东南亚国家寻求与美国建立更温暖的关系

;

;菲律宾二月份扩大了与美国的一项军事协议，允许美国军队进入另外四个基地，其中一个距离台湾不远。 4 月，两国举行了为期 18 天的联合军事演习，约有 17,000 名士兵参加。

;

;同月，菲律宾外交部长恩里克·马纳洛和时任代理国防部长小卡利托·加尔维斯在华盛顿会见了两国同行之后，美国“加倍”致力于使 1951 年签署的共同防御条约现代化，双方就南海联合巡逻计划达成一致。

;

;国际关系学教授雷纳托·克鲁兹·德卡斯特罗 (Renato Cruz De Castro)德拉萨尔大学的研究人员表示，中国对小马科斯让美国在菲律宾拥有更大战略足迹的举动感到震惊。

;

;“中国对他们认为的反华政策非常担忧， “ 他说。 “习近平正在向[杜特尔特]的追随者传递一个信息，即中国更倾向于旧政策。他希望回到菲律宾绥靖中国时的情况。”

;

;外交观察员查曼·威洛比表示，菲律宾对杜特尔特本周访华感到“措手不及”，并称其“削弱了菲律宾的机构” 。菲律宾媒体报道说，外交部并不了解这位前领导人的访问。

;

;该基金会董事会成员威洛比表示，北京认为杜特尔特可以挑战与华盛顿的联盟。总部位于马尼拉的智库国家利益组织。

;

;作为 2016 年至 2022 年总统，杜特尔特寻求与中国建立更密切的外交和经济关系，并疏远菲律宾与美国，暂停联合海军巡逻并限制军事行动

;

;据新华社报道，杜特尔特周一向习近平表示，他感谢中国对菲律宾经济和社会发展的支持，并表示他“愿意继续为促进友好关系发挥作用”

;

;“海战”：菲律宾考虑提高南海国防预算

;

;新加坡国立大学政治学教授庄嘉伊恩 (Chong Ja Ian) 表示，习近平可能会考虑提高南海防务预算。寻求解决马尼拉转向华盛顿问题的方法。

;

;“也许习近平希望杜特尔特能够利用他的声望和支持者来帮助推进[中国]在菲律宾的情况，”他说。

;

;德拉萨尔大学的克鲁兹·德卡斯特罗表示，习近平似乎“试图授权现任政府内的[杜特尔特]派系，以检查他们认为倾向于美国的政策”。

;

;该派别包括副总统萨拉·杜特尔特 (Sara Duterte) 和总统的妹妹伊梅·马科斯 (Imee Marcos)，后者曾公开反对其兄弟的外交政策。

;

;威洛比表示，挑拨菲律宾和美国之间的关系将是一场胜利对于北京来说，因为它将能够“摆脱南海问题，甚至可能摆脱台湾问题”。

;

;菲律宾靠近自治台湾意味着马尼拉可以在这一事件中发挥重要作用

;

;但克鲁兹·德卡斯特罗表示，杜特尔特不太可能对现任政府的对华政策产生太大影响。

;

;他还指出，民意调查显示，杜特尔特不太可能对现任政府的对华政策产生太大影响。菲律宾对中国高度不信任，而对美国则更有信心。 “有一件事是明确的，这将导致杜特尔特派系和那些支持现任政府的派系之间产生更大的分歧，”他说。 “这可能会导致公开对抗。”

;

;尤索夫伊萨东南亚研究所的马云表示，北京认为与马尼拉的关系比与其他东南亚国家的关系更加不稳定。

;

;“北京正在对小马科斯政府表现出战略耐心。” “然而，如果这些外交努力失败，北京可能别无选择，只能在南海发起新一波行动，将马尼拉与四方的军事和安全合作作为最后手段。”

;中国最大的在线旅游服务提供商携程集团推出了自己的大型旅游网站语言模型 (LLM) – 用于训练 ChatGPT 等聊天机器人的技术 – 预计将使人工智能 (AI) 成为客户获取准确航程数据和交易建议的重要工具。

;

;上海-周二，在线旅行社 Trip.com、Ctrip、Qunar 和 Skyscanner 的运营商在其家乡举行的一次企业活动中推出了名为“闻道”的法学硕士，“问路”在中文中大致翻译为“问路”。;

;法学硕士是深度学习人工智能算法，可以使用非常大的数据集识别、总结、翻译、预测和生成内容。

;

;旅行.com面向旅行的文道LLM仍处于测试阶段，仅面向一小部分用户开放，该文道法学硕士接受了200亿个优质旅行相关数据集的训练，并得到了公司实时数据和专有搜索算法的支持。 ”，梁说。

;

;“垂直法学硕士的机会在于 AIGC（人工智能生成的内容）遇到了巨大的挑战 - 他们的回答不可靠，”他说。

;

;该公司在一份声明中表示，为了确保问到提供最准确的答复，该集团还投入了大量人力来验证人工智能模型生成的答案的准确性。

;

;携程网的法学硕士计划随着北京通过实施法学硕士国家标准加大力度规范人工智能，反映了更广泛的中国科技行业在构建类似 ChatGPT 的服务方面缩小与西方差距的决心。

;

;中国将制定并实施国家标准人工智能模型标准

;

;在微软公司支持的初创公司OpenAI于11月推出ChatGPT之后，中国的大型科技公司纷纷开发替代服务，北京将希望寄托在人工智能开发上，以提高传统行业的效率并推动全球第二大经济体在疫情后的增长。

;

;除了利用LLM为用户提供精准的旅行信息和优惠推荐外，携程网还运用该技术来简化自身运营，公司首席执行官简孙洁周二在活动中表示。

;

;闻道已经推动了 Trip.com 基于自动在线聊天、电子邮件和热线的客户服务的使用，这些服务在 20 多个国家和地区提供。 Sun 表示。

;

;她表示，自从采用 LLM 以来，这帮助 Trip.com 的全球客户服务部门平均每天节省了 10,000 多个工作时间。

;< p>;效率的提高使得携程能够指导客户服务部门在售前活动中的工作。

;

;“我们很高兴让携程客户服务代表承担更具创造性的角色，”孙说.

;

;今年，百度、阿里巴巴、腾讯、华为和京东都已经推出了各自的LLM申请，以在各个行业得到更广泛的应用。阿里巴巴拥有《南华早报》。

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:50:02 +0800 Donald Trump claims he’s been told he’s a target in 2020 election probehttps://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3228153/donald-trump-claims-hes-been-told-hes-target-2020-election-probe?utm_source=rss_feed

;美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普周二表示，他收到了特别检察官杰克的一封信史密斯表示，他是大陪审团调查推翻 2020 年总统选举结果的目标。

;

;史密斯“发了一封信[再次，那是周日晚上！] 表示我是大陪审团调查的目标1 月 6 日大陪审团调查，”特朗普在他的真相社交媒体网站上写道。

;

;特朗普没有提供证据支持这一说法。史密斯办公室的发言人拒绝发表评论。

;

;这样的一封信可以在起诉之前发出，用于告知个人检察官有证据将他们与犯罪联系起来；特朗普在上个月因机密文件处理不当的另一项调查而被指控之前收到了一份文件。

;

;特朗普承诺，如果连任，将解密所有与肯尼迪遇刺相关的记录

;

;一个目的目标信函的目的是告知潜在被告，他或她有权出庭出席大陪审团。特朗普在帖子中表示，他被给予“非常短的 4 天时间向大陪审团报告，这几乎总是意味着逮捕和起诉”，但助手们没有立即回应寻求澄清的问题。

;

;负责领导调查的特别检察官杰克·史密斯的发言人拒绝发表评论。

;

;史密斯的团队在调查中对特朗普及其盟友试图阻止合法转移的行为进行了广泛的调查。 1 月 6 日美国国会大厦发生骚乱之前，民主党人乔·拜登掌权，当时特朗普的支持者冲进国会大厦，试图破坏国会对选举人票的认证。超过 1,000 名被指控参与骚乱的人已被指控。

;

;史密斯的调查集中在特朗普及其盟友为让他继续掌权而实施的一系列广泛计划上，包括使用所谓的“黑名单”。拜登赢得并受到特朗普争议的摇摆州的假选举人。

;

;周二晚些时候，辩护律师和联邦检察官将首次在佛罗里达州接受美国地区法官艾琳·坎农 (Aileen Cannon) 的审讯，艾琳·坎农正在主持指控特朗普是 2024 年大选中与民主党总统乔·拜登对决的共和党提名领跑者，上个月被指控在离开后非法扣留国防文件史密斯于 2021 年在办公室任职，并密谋阻碍政府找回它们。

;

;史密斯也在该案中领导起诉。

;

;台湾亿万富翁郭台铭将一个中国框架吹捧为避免这种情况的最佳方案专家表示，此举表明他并未放弃参加台湾总统选举。

;

;这位富士康创始人曾希望代表台湾主要反对党国民党参加大选。一月竞选但未能赢得提名。国民党 5 月份选举新北市长侯裕义为候选人。

;

;然而，台湾的大多数民意调查显示，侯裕义排名垫底，不仅落后于台湾副总统赖清德执政的民进党 (DPP) 以及台湾人民党的前台北市市长柯文哲，给郭台铭参选带来了希望。

;

;在《华盛顿邮报》周一发表的一篇评论文章中，郭台铭表示，表示倾向独立的民进党放弃一个中国框架的政策已使台湾成为世界上最危险的战争爆发点之一。

;

;“目前的民进党领导层只会使局势更加紧张”郭台铭说。

;

;“只是一个开始”：台湾前领导人马英九欢迎来自中国大陆的学术团队

;

;自 2016 年当选领导人以来，台湾总统蔡英文拒绝接受北京对1992年共识和一个中国原则的解释。

;

;1992年，当时由国民党领导的北京和台北达成谅解，如果双方继续谈判， ”促进了两岸数百万人次访问、大规模投资和双向贸易、经济增长、每周数百个直航航班，缓解了紧张局势，并产生了对两岸和平未来的乐观情绪。

;

;他提到北京与2008年至2016年领导台湾的前总统马英九的国民党政府签署的“一系列富有成效的协议”。

;

;郭台铭表示，蔡英文拒绝接受北京的解释将台湾纳入中国的一部分，导致大陆当局自2016年以来暂停两岸对话和交流。

;

;在这篇评论文章中，郭台铭还批评了赖以呼吁台湾减少“依赖”的做法。郭台铭表示，黎智英呼吁“无条件”与北京对话也是一厢情愿，因为如果黎智英不支持，北京不太可能接受一个中国框架。

;

;赖智于四月被民进党提名，于一月竞选总统。根据宪法规定，蔡英文在完成第二个四年任期后必须下台。

;

;在 7 月 4 日美国独立日《华尔街日报》发表的一篇评论文章中，赖智表示他没有宣布独立的计划”他们的政党将取代他们，极大地加剧了战争威胁，在国际上孤立了台湾，损害了我们的经济，吓跑了投资者，并使台湾变得更不安全。”郭台铭写道。

;

;他嘲笑民进党的描述。台湾必须掌握自己的命运，加强威慑能力，郭台铭说：“与此同时，提出一种有利于该地区和全球的和平方法，但最重要的是它自己。”北京声称对台湾拥有主权，并誓言要将该岛置于其控制之下。 ，必要时使用武力。与大多数国家一样，美国作为台湾最大的非正式盟友，并不支持台湾独立，但反对任何单方面武力改变两岸现状的行为。

;

;“我长期以来主张郭台铭表示，“立即恢复台湾与中国大陆之间的直接两岸谈判是真正缓解紧张局势并维护台湾民主、自由和法治的唯一途径。”

;

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 Brazil to investigate claims of Chinese dumping in optical cable sectorhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3228148/brazil-investigate-claims-chinese-dumping-optical-cable-sector?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 22:04;
;;

;巴西政府发起两项调查，以确定中国光缆制造企业是否在南美国家从事不公平贸易行为。

;

;巴西对外贸易秘书处将调查倾销指控——以低于市场价格的价格出口商品的贸易行为，可能会造成不公平的竞争环境巴西利亚贸易保护部门也热衷于确定这些做法是否得到了中国政府补贴的推动。此类行为将违反世界贸易组织的规则。

;

;审查表明，尽管巴西总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦努力加强与北京的外交关系，但对其经济的潜在影响仍然存在担忧，担心联合国各国和欧盟最近也发表了意见。

;

;有关调查的讨论最初于 2022 年雅伊尔·博尔索纳罗 (Jair Bolsonaro) 担任总统期间提出，但直到最近才获得批准。

;

;意大利普睿司曼、墨西哥电缆公司和日本古河电气公司这三大跨国公司对此表示支持，声称在中国竞争对手使用价格操纵策略后，他们在巴西市场蒙受了巨大损失。

;

;巴西对外贸易秘书处报告称，它发现了北京干预的“实质性证据”，包括促进光纤光缆出口公司原材料开发的补贴和激励措施。

;

;巴西利亚的调查与卢拉政府加强外交接触的努力形成鲜明对比与中国。 4月，巴西总统前往北京进行国事访问，离开时表示，在他的领导下，双边关系将达到“新水平”。

;

;2023年中国在美国后院采取的5项贸易举措拉丁美洲

;

;然而，贸易讨论仍然是一个争论点。多年来，巴西企业一直对中国企业的不公平做法表示不满。

;

;2016年，巴西最大私营部门代表组成的财团巴西全国工业联合会反对给予中国“市场”经济”地位，当供需主导商品和服务的生产时授予的标签。

;

;世贸组织规则使巴西如果获得该标签就更难对原产于中国的产品征收关税和关税。然而，该联合会辩称，北京通过世贸组织禁止的干预措施人为地维持低价。

;

;在十月份的总统竞选期间，卢拉表示，他对中国参与巴西经济感到“震惊”。他声称，有必要摆脱中国“只主宰非洲”的幻想，并认识到拉丁美洲也正在发生同样的事情。

;

;最近，卢拉和阿根廷总统阿尔贝托·费尔南德斯试图阻止乌拉圭寻求与中国达成自由贸易协定。巴西和阿根廷表示担心，不受控制的中国产品进口可能对地区经济构成威胁。

;

;负责此案的官员声称，普睿司曼、卡博纳和古河提供的证据“表明国家干预经济”因此，私营企业的决策似乎并不反映市场动态，而是反映[中国]政府制定的计划的持续指导方针。

;

;中国驻巴西利亚大使馆表示， “跟踪调查并就该问题与巴西方面举行会谈”。

;

;普睿司曼拉丁美洲电信副总裁马塞洛·安德拉德 (Marcelo Andrade) 表示，要求巴西当局进行正式调查的决定受到鼓励通过2021年和2022年有利于欧盟该行业的决议。

;

;2021年11月，欧盟委员会发现光纤电缆制造商“受益于中国国家开发银行基金的优惠贷款”，并批准反垄断- 2022年1月对来自中国的进口单模光缆征收5.1%至10.3%的倾销税。

;

;“尽管国内市场呈指数级增长，但我们一直自 2017 年以来，随着中国企业以荒谬的定价政策在巴西站稳脚跟，巴西的市场份额不断下降。欧洲的积极信号是发起正式调查请求的额外动力，因为这是一个耗时、复杂且成本高昂的过程，”安德拉德说。

;

;他还表示，在内部初步调查期间在调查请求的谈判中，他的团队发现了包括江苏中天科技有限公司、长江光纤光缆公司、烽火通信和亨通公司在内的多家中国公司存在倾销行为。这些公司均未回应置评请求。

;

;Cablena 首席商务官卡洛斯·爱德华多·德奥利维拉 (Carlos Eduardo de Oliveira) 表示，此举的目的不是阻止中国企业在巴西开展业务，而是遏制不公平竞争并创造机会该行业的公平竞争环境。

;

;本周卢拉国事访问期间，中国、巴西将签署 20 多项协议

;

;Cablena 2017 年在巴西的销售额下降了 60%奥利维拉说，在过去的六年里，该公司不得不解雇其圣保罗工厂 150 多名员工中的近一半。

;

;“这些中国公司造成的不公平竞争阻碍了投资并阻碍了投资。”技术领域新兴人才和巴西专业知识的发展。许多经济部门已经（因中国不公平的做法）受到损害，如果巴西不解决这个问题，其他部门也将遭到破坏。”奥利维拉说。

;

;这三家公司还在考虑向其他拉丁国家提出调查请求。他们经营所在的美国市场。

;

;虽然巴西实施反倾销措施相对常见，但对中国补贴的调查却相当罕见，而且经常面临政治和外交障碍。

;

;在巴西2017年，外贸秘书处官员确认了热轧钢行业的此类做法，据称至少有四家中国企业从中受益。然而，巴西部长理事会选择不征收反补贴税，理由是维持较低价格符合“公共利益”。

;

;就在去年，博尔索纳罗政府发现中国对铝层压板存在不公平补贴，但推迟征收反补贴税.

;

;但卢拉的部长会议重新审视了这一决定，并在五年内征收近 15% 的关税。

;

;北京反对这些关税，并威胁要限制某些巴西商品的进口，政府消息人士称。

;

;巴西外贸部长塔蒂亚娜·普拉泽雷斯(Tatiana Prazeres)表示，她无法对涉及其他政府的问题发表评论，但保证对作为调查基础的光缆案件的分析仅遵循技术标准。

;

;“We have no restriction on the application of a countervailing measure, either against China or against any other country, provided there is evidence to justify it,” she said.

;

;Rafaela Noman , director of the trade defence department and responsible for the investigations, also said the Brazilian government has no intention – so far – of taking the matter to the WTO appeal panels.

;

;She said that procedures of this kind were only used in very large cases. If dumping practices and the granting of subsidies by the Chinese government are proven, Brazil would probably solve the problem through countervailing measures levied when the imported products arrive on Brazilian territory.

;

;3 reasons why China and Brazil are looking to deepen trade ties

;

;Silvana Schumanski, a former visiting scholar at the WTO and now a professor at the Federal University of Pelotas, said the investigations into subsidies and dumping by Chinese companies in Brazil are an indication that Chinese trade policy, while claiming to defend multilateral trade rules, has benefited from irregular practices with significant consequences for industry in developing countries.

;

;Schumanski argued that the prevailing sentiment among industry analysts is concern that China has leveraged its economic prowess to exert pressure on less affluent countries without facing repercussions for unfair competition.

;

;“No one really wants to discuss this issue, but it is clear that the standards and rules that exist today are not sufficient to deal [with some Chinese practices]. The result is that without equal bargaining power between a stronger and a weaker country, there is room for the big players to take advantage,” Schumanski said.

;

;Xi tells Latin America-Caribbean that China will take ties to 'new era'

;

;She expected that the investigations would be closely monitored by neighbouring nations, noting that Beijing's subsidies posed a risk to Latin American countries of “perpetuating a postcolonial trade paradigm”, given the concentration of production chains in Asia, especially in China.

;

;“For decades, our industry has withstood aggressive competition from the United States. Should we now simply substitute the Americans for China? That would be decidedly detrimental for Latin American countries,” Schumanski said.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 What is making 2023 likely to be the hottest year recorded?https://www.scmp.com/news/world/article/3228149/what-making-2023-likely-be-hottest-year-recorded?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 22:14;
;;

;Human-made climate change is supercharging natural weather phenomena which is driving the heatwaves that are roasting Asia, Europe and North America – and could make 2023 the hottest year since records began, scientists say.

;

;Here, experts explain how 2023 has got so hot, warning that these record temperatures will get worse even if humanity drastically cuts its planet-warming gas emissions.

;

;After a record hot summer in 2022, this year the Pacific warming phenomenon known as El Nino has returned, heating up the oceans.

;

;“This may have provided some additional warmth to the North Atlantic, though because the El Nino event is only just beginning, this is likely only a small portion of the effect,” Robert Rohde of US temperature monitoring group Berkeley Earth wrote in an analysis.

;

;The group calculated that there was an 81 per cent chance that 2023 would become the warmest year since thermometer records began in the mid-19th century.

;

;'Hot and dangerous weekend': global heatwaves scorch the US to Asia and Europe

;

;The warming of the Atlantic may also have been sharpened by a decrease of two substances that typically reflect sunlight away from the ocean: dust blowing off the Sahara desert and sulphur aerosols from shipping fuel.

;

;Rohde's analysis of temperatures in the North Atlantic region noted “exceptionally low levels of dust coming off the Sahara in recent months.”

;

;This was due to unusually weak Atlantic trade winds, said Karsten Haustein of Germany's federal Climate Service Centre.

;

;Meanwhile new shipping restrictions in 2020 slashed toxic sulphur emissions. “This would not explain all of the present North Atlantic spike, but may have added to its severity,” Rohde noted.

;

;Warming oceans affect land weather patterns, prompting heatwaves and droughts in some places and storms in others. The hotter atmosphere sucks up moisture and dumps it elsewhere, said Richard Allan, professor of climate science at the University of Reading.

;

;Scientists highlighted the length and intensity of the lingering anticyclone systems bringing the heatwaves.

;

;“Where stagnant high-pressure areas persist over continents, the air sinks and warms, melting away clouds, causing intense summer sunshine to parch the soils, heating the ground and air above,” with heatwaves “lodged in place” for weeks, Allan said.

;

;In Europe, “the hot air which pushed in from Africa is now staying put, with settled high pressure conditions meaning that heat in warm sea, land and air continues to build,” added Hannah Cloke, a climate scientist at the University of Reading.

;

;2,000 evacuated in La Palma wildfire in Spain's Canary Islands

;

;Scientists at the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) said in their global summary report this year that climate change had made deadly heatwaves “more frequent and more intense across most land regions since the 1950s”.

;

;This month's heatwaves are “not one single phenomenon but several acting at the same time,” said Robert Vautard, director of France's Pierre-Simon Laplace climate institute. “But they are all strengthened by one factor: climate change.”

;

;Higher global temperatures make heatwaves longer and more intense. Despite being the main driver, climate change is one variable that humans can influence by reducing emissions from fossil fuels.

;

;“We are moving out of the usual and well-known natural oscillations of the climate to unchartered and more extreme territory,” said Melissa Lazenby, senior lecturer in climate change at the University of Sussex.

;

;“However, we have the ability to reduce our human influence on the climate and weather and to not create more extreme and long-lasting heatwaves.”

;

;Berkeley Earth warned the current El Nino could make Earth even hotter in 2024.

;

;The IPCC has said heatwaves risk getting more frequent and intense, though governments can limit climate change by reducing countries' greenhouse gas emissions.

;

;“This is just the beginning”, said Simon Lewis, chair of global change science at University College London. “Deep, rapid and sustained cuts in carbon emissions to net zero can halt the warming, but humanity will have to adapt to even more severe heatwaves in the future”.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 Hong Kong Book Fair vendor predicts visitor numbers will rebound to 1 million, in line with pre-coronavirus figureshttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/society/article/3228150/hong-kong-book-fair-vendor-predicts-visitor-numbers-will-rebound-1-million-line-pre-coronavirus?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 22:15;
;;

;Vendors at the Hong Kong Book Fair said they were optimistic about visitor numbers bouncing back to pre-pandemic levels when the event opens on Wednesday, but they admitted wet weather and a potential typhoon might dampen demand.

;

;Exhibitors at the annual show at the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre were at full steam ahead on Tuesday afternoon to set up their booths and books for the Wednesday opening after preparation was delayed by Typhoon Talim, which brushed past the city the day before.

;

;The typhoon No 8 signal remained in force until 4pm on Monday.

;

;Lai Yiu-keung, the deputy editor-in-chief of the Chung Hwa Book Company, a major exhibitor, said his team was in a race against time to build their booth, but insisted it was worth the effort.

;

;“I believe we will see more people come back to the fair, maybe a 10 per cent increase,” he predicted.

;

;“Last year because of the pandemic, none of the Taiwanese exhibitors could attend. This year, I look forward to seeing more exhibitors and visitors from outside Hong Kong.”

;

;Other exhibitors highlighted the new Exhibition Centre station, which gives a direct link to the Lo Wu and Lok Ma Chau border crossings by the extended East Rail line and said they were keen to welcome more mainland Chinese and overseas visitors after border restrictions were ditched earlier this year.

;

;Vicky Liu, a distributor from the mainland's Guangdong province, who arrived in Hong Kong on Tuesday morning, said that she anticipated more Chinese day trippers would visit.

;

;But she admitted the city's unstable weather this week remained a worry.

;

;“I crossed the border at Lo Wu this morning precisely because the East Rail line can come directly to the Exhibition Centre. I used to hate crossing at Lo Wu,” Liu said.

;

;“However, human traffic flow is still very dependent on the weather. If it continues raining, I am worried fewer people will come.”

;

;Sophia Chong Suk-fan, the deputy director of organisers the Trade Development Council, said she expected a 10 per cent rise in foot traffic from last year based on the proportion of overseas and mainland attendees at previous events.

;

;She also appealed to the public to spend their latest consumption vouchers – the HK$2,000 (US$256) second instalment delivered on Sunday – at the fair to help boost the economy.

;

;Hong Kong Book Fair's 760 exhibitors urged to abide by national security law

;

;“We are quite positive about the impact of consumption vouchers being issued so near to the opening of the fair. We really hope citizens will spend more, not just on books, but also on snacks and sporting equipment,” Chong said.

;

;But Ken Chan, the sales director at Cosmos Books, was less optimistic the consumption vouchers would drive sales.

;

;“People usually spend their consumption vouchers on luxury items or food, so they might not splurge on books,” Chan said.

;

;But Chan, who has exhibited at the fair for more than a decade, said that he anticipated visitor numbers would get back to pre-pandemic levels of more than a million.

;

;The fair recorded a total of 850,000 visitors last year over the seven-day event.

;

;Lai added that major bookstores like Chung Hwa would be able to accept consumption voucher payments, but that some smaller vendors might not have the same options.

;

;The theme for this year's fair is Children's and Young Adult literature, with a special focus on Hong Kong writers, including the late Ho Tsz, Chau Mat-mat, Poon Ming-chu and Poon Kam-ying.

;

;A special exhibition featuring nine writers will showcase memorabilia, including out-of-print works, manuscripts and photos.

;

;Sessions by popular novelists, like Chinese writers Yu Hua, author of To Live and Chronicle of a Blood Merchant, and Ma Boyong, who wrote The Longest Day in Chang'an, are already oversubscribed and have over a thousand people signed up.

;

;Hong Kong Book Fair 2022 closes with total of 850,000 visitors

;

;British children's author and illustrator Theodora Whittington will discuss The Sand Turtle, a picture book about environmental problems she wrote especially for Hong Kong children.

;

;The fair will also feature the World of Arts and Culture, an interactive zone designed to showcase picture books from more than 25 countries, some of which are unavailable in city bookstores.

;

;Chen Bin, an exhibitor from Guangzhou, arrived in Hong Kong amid the typhoon weather by high-speed train on Monday. His booth, designed to showcase the literature and culture of Guangdong province, is expected to be one of the highlights of the fair.

;

;He said his team had already prepared for the worst with the risk of another typhoon early next week and that they were not worried about logistics as Guangzhou was close to the city.

;

;“We braved the typhoon to get here. This fair is one of the most important ones in the Chinese cultural world – we cannot miss it,” he said.

;

;The week-long book fair will run from July 19 to 25.

;

;The event, which will be held alongside a sports fair and a snacks event, will feature 780 exhibitors from 36 countries and regions.

;

;Admission, which grants access to all three fairs, is HK$30, up from HK$25 last year.

; Tue, 18 Jul 2023 22:20:03 +0800 China’s internet firms create at least 200 million jobs amid unemployment crisis, report findshttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3228105/chinas-internet-firms-create-least-200-million-jobs-amid-unemployment-crisis-report-finds?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.18 21:30;
;;

;China's internet platform companies employ at least 200 million people, including both full-time employees and gig workers, showing the sector's vital importance to the country's economic and social stability, according to a new report by a Beijing-based venture capital firm.

;

;While many Chinese Big Tech firms have downsized their payroll amid an economic slowdown and regulatory hostility, these enterprises remain some of the largest employers for the country's labour population of 880 million, CyanHill Capital researchers said.

;

;Among gig workers or so-called platform workers, truck drivers comprise the biggest group at 16.5 million.

;

;While truck driving is a long-established occupation that plays an important role in China's vast logistics network, the emergence of online platforms has significantly changed the way drivers take orders and improved their efficiency, the report said.

;

;Over 70 per cent of China's truck drivers receive at least half of their cargo volume from more than 2,500 truck-hailing platforms nationwide, according to the report.

;

;The second-largest group of platform workers in China are ride-hailing drivers. With some 7 million active workers, it has become one of the fastest-growing occupations in the country over the past few years, the report said.

;

;The number of new licences granted to drivers increased by 32.6 per cent in 2022, and the country has been adding new drivers this year at a daily rate that is five times higher than last year's, the report found.

;

;The next largest group of gig workers in China are its 5 million delivery riders, who have expanded from dispatching just food to cover also items such as groceries, medicine and flower bouquets, especially during the Covid-19 pandemic.

;

;China has pinned high hopes on internet platforms to create jobs amid the country's flagging economy.

;

;Last week, Premier Li Qiang said in a meeting with Big Tech firms that the government will set up a regular communication mechanism with platform companies, in Beijing's strongest signal to date that it will lend its strong support to the internet industry and tone down more than two years of tight regulatory scrutiny.

;

;In praise of the tech sector, Li said platform companies have become a new engine for innovation and a new channel for job creation. “Their status is increasingly prominent in the overall economic development,” he said.

;

;China's internet platform companies – which include the operators of online services from social media and video gaming to e-commerce and food delivery – generated more than 240 million jobs for 27 per cent of the working-age population in 2021, according to the China Information Economics Society, a think tank.

;

;But the country is facing a worsening job crisis. The unemployment level of youth aged 16 to 24 reached a new high of 20.8 per cent in May, and it is expected to rise further in July and August, as a record 11.58 million university graduates are set to leave campus.

;

;Adding to the woes of young jobseekers, private companies, including tech giants, have gone through rounds of lay-offs since 2022 to cut costs.

;

;As the situation worsens, many people have turned to internet platforms for flexible employment. Ride-hailing driving has become such a popular option that some Chinese cities have stopped issuing operation permits to prevent an overflow of drivers.

;

;Apart from drivers, some of China's newest platform workers include 5 million of influencers, defined as online content creators with more than 10,000 followers, according to CyanHill.

;

;On short video apps and other social media platforms, influencers often perform the role of salespeople, while creating content that earns them financial returns based on the views and attention that it draws.

;

;Another new group of platform workers are China's 4 million programmers, whose effort keeps 3.8 million websites up and running, CyanHill said.

;

;Internet platform companies have expanded the concept of “workers”, a term that used to convey an image of factory labourers but now also covers well-educated coders, because they also do not own the means of production, CyanHill said.

;

;“To a large extent, the value and meaning of platforms are realised through absorbing, integrating and mobilising workers,” the report said. “We hope platforms can absorb more workers, and we will need the advancement of artificial intelligence and more diverse demand for that to happen.”

;;

;Hong Kong's jobless rate hit a landmark with a fall to 2.9 per cent between April and June – the first time the unemployment figure has dropped below 3 per cent since four years ago, before the coronavirus outbreak, and a signal the city has returned to full employment.

;

;Figures from the Census and Statistics Department released on Tuesday showed that the rolling total was down 0.1 percentage points from March to May, which marked a sustained economic recovery since the city removed all Covid-19 restrictions in February.

;

;Ho Kai-ming, the acting labour and welfare secretary, predicted the jobs market would continue to get better, buoyed by a continued bounce back in the economy.

;

;“The labour market should improve further in the coming months as the economic recovery gathers further strength,” he said.

;

;The latest jobless rate is the lowest since pre-pandemic 2019, when it reached 2.9 per cent in the April to June period.

;

;The up-to-date underemployment rate was 1.1 per cent, down 0.1 percentage points.

;

;About 113,600 people were out of work, but total employment increased by 15,400, from about 3.78 million to 3.8 million during the March to May period.

;

;The unemployment figure has been on a downward trend since 5.5 per cent was recorded at the end of the first quarter last year.

;

;The unemployment rates in retail declined by 0.3 percentage points to 3.5 per cent and the jobless total in the accommodation services sector dropped 0.5 percentage points to 3 per cent.

;

;Marked improvements were also recorded in the arts, entertainment and recreation sector, where unemployment fell by 0.9 percentage points from 4.2 per cent to 3.3 per cent.

;

;Hong Kong's catering, retail sectors need 100,000 workers, industry chiefs say

;

;Economist Simon Lee Siu-po, an honorary fellow at the Asia-Pacific Institute of Business at Chinese University, agreed the latest jobless figures reflected that Hong Kong had achieved full employment – but that the numbers highlighted an underlying problem.

;

;“This is caused by an exodus of people who have emigrated to other countries. This signals a lot of challenges for Hong Kong as it grapples with insufficient talent and lack of skilled workers,” explained.

;

;Lee warned the city's economic recovery might be affected because of the lack of talent and labour.

;

;“Employers will be forced to increase wages to attract people, pushing up their operating costs and, as a result, impeding economic growth.” he predicted.

;

;Hong Kong air industry asks for non-resident workers to deal with staff shortage

;

;The government announced plans last month to import 20,000 workers to ease a labour crunch in the construction, aviation and transport industries under a special scheme that will bypass vetting by union leaders as Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu said the city had lost about 200,000 people from its workforce in the past few years.

;

;Hong Kong last year suffered its biggest drop in the working population since records began in 1985, losing more than 94,000 employees. The figures brought the number of workers who quit the labour force in the past four years to 220,500.

;

;Gary Ng Cheuk-yan, a senior economist at Natixis Corporate and Investment Bank, also said the low jobless rate reflected some hidden problems.

;

;“The economic recovery is not so robust. The retail sector has rebounded, but exports have continued to face downward pressure,” he said.

;

;“It shows that the labour force participation rate is not satisfactory, leading to a low jobless rate,” Ng explained.

;

;“Amid the outflow of people, the city's employers will continue to have problems hiring people.”

;China's top safety watchdog pledged to crack down on cover-ups of deadly mine accidents as four officials were placed under investigation in northeast China following one of the country's latest mining disasters.

;

;Wang Xiangxi, head of China's Ministry of Emergency Management, the country's top agency responsible for worker safety, called for a special investigation of under-reported mining accidents, according to a statement published on the ministry website Monday night.

;

;Local officials tried to cover up scale of Chinese mine disaster, report finds

;

;“(We should) seriously carry out a special investigation to 'uncover' cover-ups of mining accidents, set up a joint mechanism to crack down on cover-ups, and increase rewards for whistle-blowers,” Wang was quoted as saying in a Monday meeting.

;

;Wang said the industry should “make curbing serious accidents a top priority, and solidly carry out special investigations and rectification actions for the hidden dangers behind major mining accidents”.

;

;Wang's call came on the same day as a local anti-corruption agency, the Commission for Discipline Inspection in the northeastern province of Liaoning, said it had put four officials under investigation for a suspected cover-up of a local mine accident. A previous official report had pinned the blame on the mine's owners.

;

;The accident in late June at the Honglin coal mine in Fuxin, Liaoning province, 600km (373 miles) northeast of Beijing, killed seven people and injured seven others.

;

;The disaster was not made public until days later, on July 4, when a local work safety committee said it had discovered the casualties and started an investigation. The governor of Liaoning travelled to the site to investigate the following day.

;

;The four Liaoning officials under investigation had been responsible for various levels of approval and safety supervision at the mine, according to an official announcement.

;

;On Sunday, the Liaoning Provincial Commission for Discipline Inspection said Lai Huaping, Fuxin's deputy mayor in charge of coal transformation, was among the officials being investigated in a suspected cover up.

;

;Several concealed mining accidents have been exposed and made public in China this year, raising doubts about official commitments to worker safety.

;

;In April, the Emergency Management Department in Hebei province reported that a county mayor and a party secretary were being investigated for hiding the number of deaths in a mining accident last September.

;

;In late June, China Newsweek, a magazine affiliated with the China News Service, published an investigation revealing that an iron mine in Xinzhou, in the central province of Shanxi, had hidden multiple deadly mine accidents between 2007 and 2022 that had left at least 17 miners dead.

;

;'Coal, this gift from God': inside the illegal people's mines of Indonesia

;

;The local government in Xinzhou said later that it would investigate the coal mine. On Monday, the Emergency Management Department in Shanxi announced it would conduct safety inspections of coal mines throughout Xinzhou.

;

;Earlier this month, the National Mine Safety Administration published the details of nine covered-up mine accidents from 2021 and 2022 on its website.

;

;The accidents happened in four different provinces, resulting in 63 deaths. A total of 421 people held accountable by authorities.
